question:
Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution provides for a bicameral Parliament of India?

SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Article 79 of the Indian Constitution provides for a bicameral Parliament.
  • It states: “There shall be a Parliament for the Union which shall consist of the President and two Houses to be known respectively as the Council of States (Rajya Sabha) and the House of the People (Lok Sabha).”
  • This establishes a bicameral legislature, meaning the Indian Parliament has two Houses.

Additional Information:

  • Rajya Sabha is the Upper House (Council of States), and Lok Sabha is the Lower House (House of the People).
  • The President of India is also an integral part of Parliament (as per Article 79).
  • Bicameralism exists at the central level, but not in all Indian states (only a few have State Legislative Councils).

question:
As per Article 172 (2)_______of a State shall NOT be subject to dissolution.

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• As per Article 172(2) of the Indian Constitution, the Legislative Council of a State shall not be subject to dissolution.
  • Unlike the Legislative Assembly (which is dissolved after its term or earlier), the Legislative Council is a permanent body.
  • One-third of its members retire every two years, ensuring continuity in the council.

Additional Information:

  • Only a few states in India have a Legislative Council (e.g., Uttar Pradesh, Maharashtra, Telangana).
  • The provision for the Legislative Council is given under Article 169.
  • The Parliament has the power to create or abolish a Legislative Council in a state based on a resolution passed by the state’s Legislative Assembly.

question:
Article 323 of the Indian Constitution deals with __________ .

SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (3rd shift)
option_1: expenses of Public Services Commissions
option_2: reports of Public Services Commissions
option_3: functions of Public Services Commissions
option_4: power to extend functions of Public Services Commissions
solution:
• Article 323 of the Indian Constitution deals with the submission of reports of Public Service Commissions to the President or Governor.
  • It mandates that both the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) and State Public Service Commissions (SPSC) must submit annual reports of their work.
  • These reports are laid before the Parliament or State Legislature, along with explanations on cases where the advice of the commission was not accepted.

Additional Information:

  • UPSC functions under Articles 315 to 323.
  • Article 323 helps maintain transparency and accountability of the commissions.
  • The President (in case of UPSC) or the Governor (in case of SPSC) ensures that these reports reach the legislative bodies.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution empowers the Supreme Court to review its own judgements or orders?

SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Article 137 of the Indian Constitution empowers the Supreme Court to review its own judgments or orders.
  • It states: “Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament or any rules made under Article 145, the Supreme Court shall have power to review any judgment pronounced or order made by it.”
  • This ensures judicial accountability and gives the Court the chance to rectify errors.

Additional Information:

  • The power of review is part of the Supreme Court’s inherent jurisdiction.
  • A Review Petition can be filed under Article 137, generally within 30 days of the judgment.
  • The review power is exercised sparingly and usually by the same bench that delivered the original judgment.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution empowers the Parliament to establish additional courts for better administration of laws made by it

SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Article 247 of the Indian Constitution empowers the Parliament to establish additional courts for the better administration of laws made by it.
  • It reads: “Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, Parliament may by law provide for the establishment of any additional courts for the better administration of laws made by Parliament or of any existing laws with respect to a matter enumerated in the Union List.”
  • This article ensures effective implementation of Union laws.

Additional Information:

  • Article 247 is applicable only to matters in the Union List (List I of the Seventh Schedule).
  • These courts can include specialized tribunals or additional judicial bodies.
  • It enhances the judicial infrastructure required for the enforcement of Central laws.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution deals with the removal and suspension of a member of the Public Service Commission?

Graduate Level 27/06/2023 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• Article 317 of the Indian Constitution deals with the removal and suspension of a member of a Public Service Commission (either UPSC or State PSC).
  • The President can order removal on grounds such as misbehavior, but in such cases, the matter must be referred to the Supreme Court for inquiry.
  • During the inquiry, the President may suspend the member.

Additional Information:

  • The procedure ensures independence and integrity of the Commission.
  • Article 317 applies to members of both the Union and State Public Service Commissions.
  • The Supreme Court’s advice is binding on the President regarding removal on misbehavior.

question:
Which part of the Indian Constitution deals with the organisation, composition and powers of the state legislature?

Graduate Level 30/06/2023 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• Part VI of the Indian Constitution deals with the organisation, composition, and powers of the State Legislature.
  • It covers the structure of State Governments, including the Governor, State Legislature (Legislative Assembly and Legislative Council, if any), and Council of Ministers.
  • Articles 168 to 212 under Part VI specifically relate to State Legislature.

Additional Information:

  • Article 168 mentions the bicameral or unicameral nature of the State Legislature.
  • Part VI applies only to States, not to Union Territories.
  • Part V, in contrast, deals with the Union Government and Parliament.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Constitution of India provides that there shall be a Legislative Assembly for the National Capital Territory of Delhi?

Higher Secondary 27/06/2023 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• Article 239AA of the Indian Constitution provides that there shall be a Legislative Assembly for the National Capital Territory (NCT) of Delhi.
  • It was inserted by the 69th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1991.
  • This article grants Delhi a special status, allowing it to have an elected legislative assembly and a council of ministers, headed by a Chief Minister.

Additional Information:

  • Though Delhi has its own Legislative Assembly, public order, police, and land remain under the control of the Central Government.
  • The Lieutenant Governor is the administrative head of Delhi.
  • Article 239AA is included under Part VIII of the Constitution (Union Territories).

question:
Which among the following is a subject of Union Lists in the Constitution of India?

SSC MTS 04/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Extradition is a subject listed in the Union List under the Seventh Schedule of the Indian Constitution.
  • It refers to the process of handing over a person (usually a criminal or fugitive) from one country or state to another.
  • As it involves international relations and national sovereignty, it falls exclusively under the Union Government's jurisdiction.

Additional Information:

  • The Union List contains subjects on which only Parliament can legislate.
  • There are 100 subjects in the Union List, including defense, foreign affairs, atomic energy, and extradition.
  • Other options like Liquor and Social Planning fall under State or Concurrent Lists, not Union.

question:
Provisions related to the seat of the "Supreme Court of India" is mentioned in which Article?

SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Article 130 of the Indian Constitution deals with the seat of the Supreme Court of India.
  • It states: “The Supreme Court shall sit in Delhi or in such other place or places, as the Chief Justice of India may, with the approval of the President, from time to time, appoint.”
  • Thus, while the default seat is Delhi, the provision allows for sittings in other locations as well.

Additional Information:

  • Till date, the Supreme Court sits only in Delhi, though there have been discussions about regional benches.
  • The idea behind flexibility in location is to promote access to justice across the country.
  • Articles 124 to 147 deal with the Supreme Court of India in the Constitution.

question:
Part XVI of the Indian constitution deals with ___________ .

SSC MTS 18/05/2023 (Morning)
option_2: Special provisions related to certain classes
option_4: Special provisions related to municipal corporation
solution:
• Part XVI of the Indian Constitution deals with special provisions relating to certain classes, such as Scheduled Castes (SCs), Scheduled Tribes (STs), and Other Backward Classes (OBCs).
  • It includes provisions for reservation in legislatures, representation, and other safeguards for these communities.

Additional Information:

  • Part XVI covers Articles 330 to 342.
  • Key provisions include:
    • Article 330 – Reservation of seats for SCs and STs in the Lok Sabha.
    • Article 332 – Reservation in the State Legislative Assemblies.
    • Article 335 – Claims of SCs and STs in services and posts.
  • These provisions aim at ensuring social justice and political representation for disadvantaged groups.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Indian constitution provides for the National commission for Scheduled Castes?

SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Article 338 of the Indian Constitution provides for the National Commission for Scheduled Castes (NCSC).
  • This article outlines the powers, functions, composition, and responsibilities of the Commission.
  • The NCSC is responsible for safeguarding the interests of Scheduled Castes and ensuring the implementation of constitutional safeguards.

Additional Information:

  • Originally, Article 338 dealt with both SCs and STs.
  • After the 89th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2003, a separate National Commission for Scheduled Tribes was created under Article 338A.
  • The NCSC submits annual reports to the President of India, who lays them before Parliament.

question:
Provisions related to the Municipalities are mentioned under which part of the Indian constitution?

SSC MTS 16/06/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Part IXA of the Indian Constitution deals with provisions related to Municipalities.
  • It was added by the 74th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1992.
  • This part provides a constitutional status to urban local bodies like Municipal Corporations, Municipal Councils, and Nagar Panchayats.

Additional Information:

  • Part IXA includes Articles 243P to 243ZG.
  • It covers composition, powers, elections, and functioning of urban local self-government.
  • The aim is to strengthen decentralization and improve urban governance.

question:
Which Article of the Indian constitution mentions that it is duty of the Union government to protect States against external aggression and internal disturbance?

SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Article 355 of the Indian Constitution states that it is the duty of the Union to protect every State against external aggression and internal disturbance.
  • It also ensures that the Government of every State is carried on in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution.
  • This article provides the basis for central intervention in state matters when national security or constitutional machinery is at risk.

Additional Information:

  • Article 355 is part of Part XVIII of the Constitution – Emergency Provisions.
  • It serves as a justification for actions like President’s Rule (Article 356) when there is constitutional failure in a state.
  • It is not an emergency itself but a protective obligation of the Centre.

question:
Which Article of the constitution of India is related to the Comptroller and Auditor General of India Audit reports?

SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Article 151 of the Indian Constitution relates to the audit reports of the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India.
  • It states that the reports of the CAG on the accounts of the Union and the States shall be submitted to the President or Governor, who shall then lay them before Parliament or the State Legislature respectively.

Additional Information:

  • Article 148 deals with the appointment and duties of the CAG.
  • Article 149 outlines the powers and responsibilities of the CAG.
  • Article 150 specifies how the accounts are to be maintained, as prescribed by the President.
  • These provisions together ensure transparency and accountability in the financial administration of the country.

question:
Central Bureau of Intelligence and Investigation comes under which list of the seventh schedule of the Indian constitution?

SSC CHSL 14/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Central Bureau of Intelligence and Investigation, such as agencies like the CBI, comes under the Union List of the Seventh Schedule of the Indian Constitution.
  • The Union List contains subjects on which only the Parliament has the power to make laws.
  • Police and Public Order are state subjects, but central intelligence and investigation agencies operate under the Union List for matters of national importance.

Additional Information:

  • Entry 8 of the Union List refers to: "Central Bureau of Intelligence and Investigation."
  • Other related entries include defense, external affairs, and atomic energy, all matters requiring centralized control.
  • The CBI derives its powers from the Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, 1946, under central jurisdiction.

question:
The part VII of the Indian constitution has been omitted. It is related with which of the following?

SSC CHSL 14/03/2023 (4th Shift)
option_1: Provision relating to property
option_2: States in part B of the first schedule
option_3: Armed forces in states in part A of the second schedule
option_4: Reservation for Anglo- Indian communities in parliament
solution:
• Part VII of the Indian Constitution was originally related to the States in Part B of the First Schedule.
  • It dealt with provisions for the former princely states which were merged into the Indian Union after independence.
  • This part became redundant after the 7th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1956, which reorganized states and abolished the distinction between Part A, B, and C states.

Additional Information:

  • Part VII was omitted by the Constitution (7th Amendment) Act, 1956.
  • The First Schedule originally classified states into Part A, B, C, and D, but now all are simply termed as States and Union Territories.
  • The reorganization was based on the recommendations of the States Reorganisation Commission.

question:
The Indian parliament has power to impose restrictions on trade, commerce and intercourse through which Article of the Indian constitution?

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• Article 302 of the Indian Constitution empowers the Parliament to impose restrictions on trade, commerce, and intercourse between states or within the territory of India in the interest of the public.
  • This article grants the Union government the authority to regulate inter-state trade to ensure economic balance and national interest.

Additional Information:

  • It belongs to Part XIII of the Constitution, which deals with Trade, Commerce and Intercourse within the territory of India.
  • While Article 301 guarantees freedom of trade and commerce, Article 302 allows reasonable restrictions when necessary.
  • Parliament can use this power even if it violates Article 301, provided it's in the public interest.

question:
Which Article of the Indian constitution states that "Governor has power to promulgate ordinances during recess of legislature"?

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Article 213 of the Indian Constitution empowers the Governor of a state to promulgate ordinances when the Legislative Assembly (or both Houses, in case of a bicameral legislature) is not in session.
  • These ordinances have the same force and effect as a law passed by the state legislature but must be approved within 6 weeks of reassembly.

Additional Information:

  • The Governor can issue an ordinance only when he is satisfied that circumstances require immediate action.
  • This power is similar to the President’s ordinance-making power under Article 123.
  • If not approved in time, the ordinance ceases to operate.

question:
Part V chapter II of the Indian constitution does not include which of the following provisions?

SSC CHSL 20/03/2023 (1st Shift)
option_1: Joint sitting of both house of Parliament in certain cases
option_2: Power of President to promulgate Ordinances during recess of Parliament
option_3: Language to be used in Parliament
option_4: Restriction on discussion in Parliament
solution:
• Part V, Chapter II of the Indian Constitution deals with Parliament and includes provisions related to its composition, functioning, procedures, and powers.
  • However, the Power of the President to promulgate ordinances during the recess of Parliament is covered under Article 123, which is part of Chapter I (The Executive) of Part V, not Chapter II.

Additional Information:

  • Option (a): Joint sitting is covered under Article 108 – included in Chapter II.
  • Option (c): Language in Parliament is covered under Article 120 – included in Chapter II.
  • Option (d): Restrictions on discussions (e.g., conduct of judges) are covered under Article 121 – also part of Chapter II.
  • Hence, only Option (b) falls outside Chapter II of Part V.

question:
Article 243K of the Indian constitution is related with which of the following?

SSC CHSL 20/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Durations of panchayat, etc.
option_2: Grounds of disqualification from membership of Panchayat.
option_3: Reservation of seats in Panchayat.
option_4: Election to the Panchayats.
solution:
• Article 243K of the Indian Constitution deals with Elections to the Panchayats.
  • It provides that the State Election Commission will be responsible for superintendence, direction, and control of the preparation and conduct of panchayat elections.
  • It ensures free and fair elections to the rural local bodies.

Additional Information:

  • Article 243K is part of Part IX of the Constitution, which deals with the Panchayati Raj System.
  • The State Election Commission is constituted under this Article for each state.
  • It is modeled similarly to the powers of the Election Commission of India under Article 324.

question:
Article 350A of the Indian constitution is related with______.

SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Special officers for linguistic minorities
option_2: Facilities for instruction in mother-tongue at primary stage
option_3: Direction for development of the Hindi language
option_4: Language to` be used in Supreme Court and High Courts of India
solution:
• Article 350A of the Indian Constitution is related to facilities for instruction in the mother-tongue at the primary stage of education.
  • It directs every State and local authority to provide adequate facilities for children belonging to linguistic minority groups to receive primary education in their mother tongue.

Additional Information:

  • This provision promotes linguistic inclusiveness and helps preserve cultural identity.
  • It was added by the 7th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1956.
  • Article 350A is part of the Directive Principles and Language-related provisions under Part XVII of the Constitution.

question:
Which part of the Constitution of India consists of the idea of a Welfare State?

SSC CGL Tier II (02/03/2023)
option_1: Directive Principles of State Policy
solution:
• The idea of a Welfare State in the Indian Constitution is embodied in the Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP).
  • These are enshrined in Part IV (Articles 36 to 51) of the Constitution.
  • They aim to promote social and economic justice, and guide the state in establishing a just and equitable society.

Additional Information:

  • The concept is inspired by the Irish Constitution.
  • DPSPs are non-justiciable, meaning they are not legally enforceable by courts, but are fundamental in governance.
  • Key principles include:
    • Equal pay for equal work
    • Right to education
    • Promotion of the welfare of people

question:
Which Article of the Constitution does India mention that business in Parliament shall be transacted in Hindi or English?

SSC CGL 05/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• Article 120 of the Indian Constitution states that the business in Parliament shall be transacted in Hindi or English.
  • However, a member who cannot adequately express themselves in either language is allowed to address the House in their mother tongue, with the permission of the Presiding Officer.

Additional Information:

  • This Article ensures linguistic inclusivity while maintaining official proceedings primarily in Hindi and English.
  • Article 120 falls under Part V, Chapter II of the Constitution, which deals with the Parliament.
  • It helps in balancing national language policies with individual language rights of members.

question:
Which Article of Indian constitution is related with the Special provisions with respect to the State of Sikkim?

SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Article 371F of the Indian Constitution contains special provisions with respect to the State of Sikkim.
  • It was added by the 36th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1975, when Sikkim became the 22nd state of India.
  • The Article aims to preserve the cultural, economic, and social identity of Sikkim and includes provisions for the Legislative Assembly and laws applicable in the state.

Additional Information:

  • Article 371F allows the Legislative Assembly of Sikkim to have certain powers different from other states.
  • It also protects existing laws in Sikkim that may be inconsistent with the Indian Constitution.
  • Similar special provisions exist for other states like Nagaland (Article 371A), Manipur (Article 371C), etc.

question:
Which Article of the Constitution of India deals with the appointment of ad- hoc judges?

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Article 127 of the Indian Constitution deals with the appointment of ad-hoc judges in the Supreme Court.
  • If there is a lack of quorum of Judges in the Supreme Court to hold or continue any session, the Chief Justice of India (CJI), with the previous consent of the President, may request a High Court judge to sit and act as an ad-hoc judge of the Supreme Court.

Additional Information:

  • The judge so appointed must be qualified to be a Supreme Court judge.
  • During this period, the judge exercises all the jurisdiction, powers, and privileges of a Supreme Court judge.
  • This provision ensures that the functioning of the Supreme Court is not hampered due to temporary vacancies.

question:
Which Article of the Constitution of India deals with the Sessions of the Parliament?

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Article 85 of the Indian Constitution deals with the Sessions of the Parliament, including summoning, prorogation, and dissolution of either House.
  • It empowers the President to summon each House of Parliament from time to time, ensuring that no more than six months pass between two sessions.

Additional Information:

  • The President acts on the advice of the Council of Ministers while summoning or dissolving the Houses.
  • Parliament generally meets in three sessions each year: Budget, Monsoon, and Winter.
  • Article 85 corresponds to the British convention of King-in-Parliament.

question:
Which chapter of the Constitution of India, discusses the Articles of Parliament?

SSC MTS 25/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The Articles related to the Parliament of India are discussed in Chapter II of Part V of the Indian Constitution.
  • Chapter II is titled “Parliament” and includes provisions about the composition, powers, functions, procedures, and offices of both the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha.

Additional Information:

  • Chapter II (Articles 79 to 122) covers:
    • Composition of Parliament (Article 79)
    • Rajya Sabha and Lok Sabha (Articles 80–81)
    • Officers like Speaker, Deputy Speaker, Chairman (Articles 93–97)
    • Procedures, privileges, and conduct of business (Articles 100–122)
  • It is part of Part V, which is dedicated to The Union.

question:
The Article of the Indian Constitution that deals with all the executive powers of the Governor is ____

SSC CHSL 24/05/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• Article 154 of the Indian Constitution deals with all the executive powers of the Governor of a state.
  • It states that the executive power of the State shall be vested in the Governor and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him.

Additional Information:

  • This Article is equivalent to Article 53 at the Union level (which vests executive power in the President).
  • The Governor is the constitutional head of the state, and all executive actions are taken in his name.
  • However, the real executive powers are exercised by the Council of Ministers, headed by the Chief Minister.

question:
Which Part of the Indian Constitution provides for the Union Public Service Commission?

SSC CHSL 27/05/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) is provided for under Part XIV of the Indian Constitution.
  • Part XIV is titled "Services under the Union and the States", and it includes provisions related to recruitment and conditions of service of persons serving under the government.

Additional Information:

  • Part XIV consists of Articles 308 to 323.
  • Article 315 to 323 specifically deal with the Public Service Commissions (both Union and State).
  • Article 315 provides for the establishment of UPSC and State PSCs.
  • Article 316 to Article 319 deal with their appointments, terms, and removal procedures.

question:
Article ______ of the Indian Constitution states that ‘there shall be a Commission for the socially and educationally backward classes to be known as the National Commission for Backward Classes’.

SSC CGL 19/04/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Article 338B(1) of the Indian Constitution states that “there shall be a Commission for the socially and educationally backward classes to be known as the National Commission for Backward Classes (NCBC)”.
  • This article was inserted by the 102nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 2018 to give constitutional status to the NCBC.

Additional Information:

  • The NCBC is responsible for monitoring the implementation of safeguards and welfare measures for OBCs (Other Backward Classes).
  • Article 338B outlines its composition, powers, functions, and reporting mechanism.
  • The Commission has the authority to investigate and inquire into matters related to OBC rights and submit reports to the President.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Constitution of India states that Hindi in Devanagari script shall be the official language of the Union?

SSC MTS 27/10/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• Article 343(1) of the Indian Constitution states that Hindi in the Devanagari script shall be the official language of the Union.
  • This Article came into effect on 26 January 1950, the day the Constitution was enacted.

Additional Information:

  • Article 343(2) allowed the continued use of English for official purposes for 15 years (till 1965).
  • Article 343(3) empowers Parliament to make laws for the continued use of English beyond the 15-year period.
  • This Article is part of Part XVII of the Constitution, which deals with Official Language.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the constitution of India provides for the creation of a GST Council?

SSC CGL 16/08/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• Article 279A of the Indian Constitution provides for the creation of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) Council.
  • This article was inserted by the 101st Constitutional Amendment Act, 2016, which introduced the GST regime in India.

Additional Information:

  • The GST Council is responsible for making recommendations on rates, exemptions, thresholds, and other GST-related policies.
  • It is chaired by the Union Finance Minister, with State Finance Ministers as members.
  • Articles related to GST:
    • Article 246A – Special power to make laws on GST.
    • Article 269A – Distribution of GST revenue between Centre and States.

question:
According to which of the following Articles of the Constitution of India shall a Money Bill NOT be introduced in the Council of States?

SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• As per Article 109 of the Indian Constitution, a Money Bill shall not be introduced in the Council of States (Rajya Sabha).
  • It can only be introduced in the Lok Sabha, and that too only on the recommendation of the President.

Additional Information:

  • A Money Bill deals exclusively with matters like taxation, borrowing of money by the government, expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India, etc.
  • After passing in the Lok Sabha, the bill is sent to the Rajya Sabha, which can recommend changes within 14 days, but the Lok Sabha is not bound to accept them.
  • The Speaker of the Lok Sabha has the final authority to decide whether a bill is a Money Bill or not.

question:
As per Article ______ of the Constitution of India, English is the official language for all the high courts in the country.

SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• As per Article 348(1) of the Indian Constitution, English shall be the official language for:
    • All proceedings in the Supreme Court and High Courts.
    • Bills, Acts, Ordinances, orders, rules, and regulations issued by the Parliament and State Legislatures.

Additional Information:

  • However, under Article 348(2), the Governor of a state can authorize the use of the state’s official language in High Court proceedings, with the prior consent of the President.
  • This ensures uniformity in the judicial system while allowing linguistic flexibility under regulated circumstances.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Constitution of India defines for a separate secretarial staff for each House of the Parliament?

SSC CGL 18/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• Article 98 of the Indian Constitution provides for separate secretarial staff for each House of Parliament – Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha.
  • It ensures that each House has its own administrative and support staff to carry out independent and efficient functioning.

Additional Information:

  • Article 98 also empowers Parliament to regulate the recruitment and conditions of service of the secretarial staff.
  • The secretariat functions under the control of the Presiding Officer of the respective House (Speaker for Lok Sabha, Chairman for Rajya Sabha).
  • This provision helps maintain the autonomy of each House in its day-to-day functioning.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Constitution of India states that there would be no tax levied or collected EXCEPT by the authority of law?

SSC CGL 24/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• Article 265 of the Indian Constitution states that “No tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law.”
  • This means that taxation must be backed by a legal provision passed by the legislature — no arbitrary taxes can be imposed by the executive.

Additional Information:

  • This Article ensures financial accountability and legality in taxation.
  • It is a safeguard for citizens, protecting them from unauthorized or illegal taxation.
  • It is part of Part XII of the Constitution, which deals with Finance, Property, Contracts, and Suits.

question:
Under which Article of the Indian Constitution are special provisions provided to language spoken in a section of the population?

SSC CGL 05/03/2020 (Evening)
solution:
• Article 347 of the Indian Constitution empowers the President to recognize a language spoken by a section of the population of a state.
  • If a substantial proportion of a state’s population desires the use of their language, the President may direct the Governor to provide for its official recognition.

Additional Information:

  • This Article ensures linguistic rights for communities whose language is not the primary official language of the state.
  • It helps promote cultural diversity and inclusiveness within the Indian federal structure.
  • The provision is particularly important for linguistic minorities.
